issues.title: resolver behavior matrix
issues.author: pspacek
issues.body:
Describe what resolver does with different combinations of:

- resolver does/not support DELEG
- auth zone does/not support DELEG
- auth zone does/not contain DELEG
- auth zone does/not contain NS

comments.author: pspacek
comments.body:
This is now implemented in https://github.com/ietf-wg-deleg/draft-ietf-deleg-base/blob/main/query-answer-combinations-table-gen.py with result available in https://github.com/ietf-wg-deleg/draft-ietf-deleg-base/blob/main/query-answer-combinations-table-gen.csv.

Now the question is in what form do we put this into draft (or not).

issues.title: one-off or type range
issues.author: pspacek
issues.body:
Do we want to define special behavior for DELEG as a single type, or do we want to reserve a range for this purpose?

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/dd/gUX9zpGAta2wwXIe-Aar7KJSZ24/

issues.title: do NOT fallback from DELEG to NS
issues.author: pspacek
issues.body: During interim we seemed to agree resolvers MUST NOT fallback to NS when DELEG they got does not work. Put text to that effect into the draft.

issues.title: Extended DNS Error for weird DE=0 corner cases
issues.author: pspacek
issues.body:
DELEG-only delegation in zone and query with DE=0 produces confusing (but RFC4033-valid) NXDOMAIN. We can have an EDE code to signal this weird corner case to people debugging this.

Source: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/dd/jrXRh99606L0z7nfvTlh8e5rwjQ/

issues.title: SVCB reuse/RR format question
issues.author: pspacek
issues.body:
## Options
- reuse SVCB wire format and presentation format (version -00)
- reuse SVCB wire format but use different presentation format (ALIAS -> INCLUDE etc.)
- reuse SVCB wire & presentation format elements like `key=value` list but do other changes, e.g. drop priority field
- do our own thing completely (nobody is seriously suggesting this, but hey, complete list of options!)

## Considerations
### Presentation format
People already got confused by "ALIAS" mode with multiple targets, which is something we definitively want to do for DELEG.

### Code reuse
- 100% compatibility not possible - we have to use new type number, so libraries need an update in any case
- benefit - easier to implement if you just add number to an existing type implementation
- problem - **too easy** to implement, so e.g. multiple ALIAS RRs might trip over code in existing strict SVCB parsers and similar problems

issues.title: Glue behavior
issues.author: pspacek
issues.body:
Discuss!

### In-domain delegation
- Is ipv4hint just a hint and should it be overriden by data from child?
- If not, do we need a name at all?

### Sibling glue
Should it have IP addresses as well?

### [Glue for Cyclic Sibling Domain Name Servers](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9471#name-glue-for-cyclic-sibling-dom)
Do we really need to support this?

### Unnecessary glue
What to do when resolver encounters it in DELEG RR?

comments.author: pspacek
comments.body: P.S. Perhaps we should get rid of term `glue`.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: Would have to agree - the last rev of terminology document we went with "sibling domain relationship" for example

issues.title: Example A.5.2. Query for foo.test is incorrect
issues.author: pspacek
issues.body:
Issue transferred from https://github.com/fl1ger/deleg/issues/48

Version: -00

@chantra reported:
I believe A.5.2 (DO bit set, DE bit set) https://github.com/fl1ger/deleg/blob/main/draft-wesplaap-deleg.md?plain=1#L404-L427 incorrectly copied the payload from A.3.2 (DO bit set, DE bit clear)

and instead should be:

```
;; Header: QR AA RCODE=0
;;

;; Question
foo.test.   IN MX

;; Answer
;; (empty)

;; Authority
test.      300 IN DELEG 0 ns2.example.net
test.      300 IN RRSIG DELEG 13 4 300 20250214164848 (
                        20250207134348 21261 . 98Aac9f7A1Ac26Q..= )
test.      300 IN NSEC  a.test. RRSIG NSEC DELEG
test.      300 IN RRSIG NSEC 13 4 300  20250214164848 (
                        20250207134348 21261 . kj7YY5tr9h7UqlK..= )

;; Additional
;; (empty)
```

issues.title: SERVFAIL DE=0 queries to/under DELEG-only delegation point
issues.author: pspacek
issues.body:
Two participants (so far) expressed desire NOT to return NXDOMAIN when DE=0 query hits a DELEG-only delegation.

- [Johan Stenstam](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/dd/nohd8lIUxFCEayxttALWyFc5SXU/)
- [Stephane Bortzmeyer](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/dd/Mv7SpCuJt7mSjf3vv9oW8wtc_YI/)

Given RFC4034 + RFC 6840 DNSSEC semantics,  the only alternative option is a deliberate SERVFAIL from the auth.

issues.title: Downgrade protection
issues.author: pspacek
issues.body:
(A hairy attempt to move old issue https://github.com/fl1ger/deleg/issues/19 to this repo.)

TL;DR version:

Without introducing an extra check, an attacker could strip DELEG RRset from a referral response and replace it with an unsigned (and potentially malicious) NS RRset. A referral response with an unsigned NS and signed DS RRsets does not require additional proofs of nonexistance according to pre-DELEG DNSSEC specification and it would have been accepted as a delegation without DELEG RRset.

comments.author: pspacek
comments.body:
[Comment](https://github.com/RoyArends) by @RoyArends:

A DELEG compliant, authoritative nameserver will include signed DELEG records, or authenticated denial of DELEG records. However, an adversary can remove these records from a response, and the resolver will treat the response as a legacy response, since there is no signed indication that DELEG or its authenticated denial should have been present.

Two methods of signed indication have been proposed.

1) DNSKEY flag.

The DNSKEY RR contains a 16 bit flag field in the RDATA. Of these, 3 have been allocated. The ZONE, REVOKE and Secure Entry Point (SEP) flag. Trivially, a fourth can be added, such as a DELEG flag. A validating resolver that observes a DELEG flag MUST expect either a signed DELEG record in a referral, or an authenticated denial record in a referral.

Advantage of this method is that it requires no additional space in a response for the signed indication. 
A potential disadvantage is that state needs to be kept between observing the DELEG flag and parsing a response.
A potential disadvantage is that legacy validators may not understand the DELEG flag and ignore the key completely. That behavior  is NOT standards compliant. This needs to be tested.

2) DS record.

The DS record contains a digest field. If the validator does not recognise the digest field value, then the DS record should be ignored. This protects legacy validators from failing over unknown DS records, and in addition, it can be used as an indicator that a DELEG or its denial should be present.

Advantage of this method is that it is "legacy validator safe" (but must be tested regardless) and that the resolver doesn't have to look at the key, since the signal is in the reponse.
A disadvantage is that this is NOT what the DS record was meant to do, i.e. Yet Another Hack.
A disadvantage is that it causes yet another record in a response that already contains NS, DS, DELEG/NSEC/NSEC3 and RRSIGs.

comments.author: pspacek
comments.body:
[Comment](https://github.com/fl1ger/deleg/issues/19#issuecomment-1832810251) by @bemasc:

Re 1: I think we should probably call this the "NSEC(3) referral flag", with the promise being "any secure delegation will be accompanied by an NSEC(3) record".  Details aside, my point is that if we decide to add new RR types to delegation points in the future, they should also be protected by this flag.

comments.author: pspacek
comments.body:
[Comment](https://github.com/fl1ger/deleg/issues/19#issuecomment-1832816617) by @RoyArends:

Good point! That makes the flag more generic and future proof. If the flag is set, expect authenicated denial in a referral. Always.

comments.author: pspacek
comments.body:
[Comment](https://github.com/fl1ger/deleg/issues/19#issuecomment-1833539316) by @peterthomassen:

Re 2:

> A disadvantage is that this is NOT what the DS record was meant to do, i.e. Yet Another Hack.

We can change what the DS record is meant to do; my take is that it might be OK if done "minimally invasive" (= without risking yet more hacks in the future).

The desire for delegation-specific flags controlled by the parent has come up a few times:

- DELEG signaling as discussed here
- Parent signaling some kind of organizational (non-)boundary (--> DBOUND?)
- DNSSEC multi-algorithm validation policy (AND vs OR in multi-signer setups with several algorithms)

Obviously, all of that is tentative; other use cases are also conceivable. Alas, the DS record (unlike the DNSKEY record) has no flags, which seems like an omission.

By reserving a hash digest number and repurposing the keytag+algorithm fields, one obtains 24 bits that can be used as flags.

I think we should ponder whether it's time to address this gap once and for all, by adding this signaling capability as a generic mechanism, which DELEG then can build on.

(One might reply that once DELEG is there, delegation-specific signaling can be done via DELEG parameters. At least for the second use case above, that's not the case though. Who knows what the future will bring.)

comments.author: pspacek
comments.body:
[Comment](https://github.com/fl1ger/deleg/issues/19#issuecomment-1900592004) by @bemasc:

Are you saying that DELEG can't be used for DBOUND?  I don't see why not.  I can certainly imagine a DELEG parameter indicating whether the delegation is "in house", or perhaps conveying even richer metadata about the organizational relationship.

comments.author: pspacek
comments.body:
[Comment](https://github.com/fl1ger/deleg/issues/19#issuecomment-1903768057) by @peterthomassen:

> Are you saying that DELEG can't be used for DBOUND?

No, I'm not saying that.

My point was that a signaling mechanism would be a nice thing to have in various situations, not only for protecting DELEG against downgrade. I was trying to widen the scope of the discussion to see if thinking about a more general signaling solution would be worthwhile (instead of inventing one for DELEG downgrade protection and another one for another purpose).

> I can certainly imagine a DELEG parameter indicating whether the delegation is "in house"

Maybe, maybe not. There may be multiple DELEG records, e.g. in a multi-provider setup. What are the implications of (not?) having to repeat this parameter in each of them?

comments.author: pspacek
comments.body:
[Comment](https://github.com/fl1ger/deleg/issues/19#issuecomment-2210725414) by @pspacek:

My preference is a new DNSKEY flag with a twist: Explicitly specified behavior that presence of this new flag in **any** DNSKEY present on zone apex turns on new behavior in (i.e. even a single DNSKEY with this flag).

The main reason is that it gives operators direct control over the flag and ability to react quickly when something goes wrong in the initial rollout.

- changing the flag does not require coordination with parent/registry
- DNSKEY can have short TTL before the flag get flipped, TTL is under operator's control
- because flag=1 in a single DNSKEY is enough the operator does not have to change existing DNSKEYs at all!
  - For the initial rollout the operator can introduce a dummy DNSKEY like `example. DNSKEY 1024 0 251` (1024 being the new flag value, with no key blob, and with intentionally unknown algorithm).
  - This dummy DNSKEY now acts only as flags container and nothing else, and old validators will just ignore it.
  - This dummy DNSKEY can be easily pulled back when needed without doing key rollover etc.
  - If the operator is comfortable with the new behavior the flag can get incorporated into regular KSK and/or ZSK on operator's schedule and then then dummy DNSKEY can be dropped

I sort of agree with https://github.com/fl1ger/deleg/issues/19#issuecomment-1832810251. It should apply to all new parent-side types (e.g. like https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-peetterr-dnsop-parent-side-auth-types-00.txt)

comments.author: pspacek
comments.body: Thank you and apologies for long wait. I thought I set notifications for this repo ... but in fact I did not :facepalm:

pulls.title: Add helper to generate possible query-answer combinations for DELEG
pulls.author: pspacek
pulls.body:
Quick hack to generate giant table with all sensible and some less-sensible
combinations of query parameters, zone content, and server software versions.
Output is a table in CSV format.
It is intended as exploratory tool so we don't forget some corner case.

The tool pre-generates "answer" according to my understanding of the protocol
and my personal taste but it does NOT represent the only possible outcome of
the design process. Reasons why it generates given "answer" are given in
answer() function.

File query-answer-combinations-table-gen.csv shows pre-generated table from the script.

pulls.title: Lots of editorial changes about authoritative servers
pulls.author: paulehoffman

comments.author: pspacek
comments.body: I've changed the base branch so we can actually see only your changes for purpose of this review.

comments.author: pspacek
comments.body: Thank you - it definitely reads better than my quick&dirty version! I would be happy to merge this after we solve the technical changes pointed out in comments.

comments.author: pspacek
comments.body: Incorporated in #22, closing here to avoid confusion.
I find this confusing. Signing IS affected by presence of DELEG records, but the proofs we send back to clients are not affected by DE bit in the query.
Nit: Personally instead of 'use' I would say 'understand' or 'support' or something like that. But that's probably matter of taste.
Does 'legacy referral response' need to be defined?
Nit: I find repetition in section title unpleasant as it will explode table of contents. But that's again personal preference.

This line has changed meaning. The original said that NXDOMAIN will happen for "for subdomains of such zone which does actually exist for DELEG aware clients.". The new text says NXDOMAIN always, which would be incorrect (as in, cannot be DNSSEC-validated) if client asked e.g. for "example. TXT".
Second comment: I'm not happy with referencing DO bit at all. I think we better leave the definition what needs to be proven when and to whom to DNSSEC spec.

OK, then I misunderstood your original. You had "DNSSEC signing is unaffected by this instruction, i.e. no special handling for NSEC type bitmap is necessary." I propose to remove the sentence and we'll add something later about the proofs and about the DNSKEY flag.
"Use" is much more direct than those two.
Well, "legacy" is defined earlier in the document, so I don't think so.
Given that you have four level-4 heads that look alike, differentiating is good for the reader.

For the first comment, I agree that I left that off accidentally. It should instead end with "for subdomains of zones which would exist for DELEG-aware clients".
For the second one, I'm not sure what to do. Proof-of-nonexistence only exists for DNSSEC, and because we are talking about what to return, you only return a proof-of-nonexistence if DO=1, correct?
I mean - there's difference between 'I understand but will not use it' and 'WTF Martians just landed in my zone file?!'.
"Use" is stil better because it is more direct.
